22.12.text: Good morning everyone. I'm joined today by Tris Lumley

24.66.text: who's Head of Development at NPC, a UK based

27.96.text: organisation that helps the social sector measure their

31.33.text: impact in the work they're undertaking.

33.83.text: He's also head of the Inspiring Impact initiative which

36.47.text: aims to improve impact measurement in the

38.30.text: UK by the year 2022. Thanks very much for joining us Tris.

43.58.text: Can you tell us a little - little bit about the

45.55.text: work of NPC and, and what you're, what you're

48.08.text: doing across the UK with the social sector?

50.08.text: Sure. So yeah, we're a, we're a charity ourselves.

54.49.text: We're a consultancy and a think-tank and

57.26.text: our aim is to transform the charity sector.

60.93.text: By "transform" we mean to help the sector achieve its

64.56.text: maximum possible social impact and we do that both

69.00.text: by working with organisations directly as

71.00.text: consultants but also by trying to identify the

73.87.text: really big issues, challenges, barriers that face

77.31.text: organisations, that face charities and social

79.45.text: enterprises, trying to explore different ways of

82.38.text: doing things and then working with the whole field

85.65.text: to - to try and make progress. And one of the

88.05.text: really big areas on which we've been working for

90.52.text: the last 10 years now is impact measurement.

93.83.text: And what does the word "impact" mean in impact

99.20.text: Well, I guess there - there's the - you know -

101.03.text: there are the technical definitions. So - you know

103.57.text: - we mean the - we mean the difference that a

105.91.text: programmer or an organisation has made that wouldn't

108.71.text: have occurred otherwise once you've taken into

111.51.text: account the dead weight and the attribution and

114.41.text: all - all of these technical terms. So that's -

117.05.text: that's one set of definitions. But for me the most

120.25.text: important one really is that we're talking about

122.72.text: the difference that you make in someone's life and

125.83.text: this is a pretty straightforward thing - you know.

127.83.text: This is about change and so as much as possible I

131.90.text: try to - to focus on sort of the really broad

135.90.text: meaning of the word "impact" and - and the - the

138.51.text: really direct one that makes sense to the people

140.51.text: who you're working with. So I think if we start to

142.91.text: get into really hugely technical jargon

145.81.text: discussions then we've already lost a lot of the

148.48.text: people that we're trying to bring along with us.

151.08.text: And why do you think it's important for the

152.55.text: social sector itself rather than government to be interested

155.32.text: in impact measurement? In Australia it's typically been

158.02.text: government that's perhaps led this work. Why is it

160.53.text: important for the social sector itself do you think?

163.93.text: I think the - the, the fact that maybe that -

167.27.text: that government and funders maybe have been in the

169.27.text: driving seat and not the social sector, I think

171.94.text: tells us something about our understanding of the

173.94.text: word "impact". And so for me - you know - impact

177.94.text: gets turned into two different things. If, if

181.31.text: you're running a charity or a social enterprise

183.32.text: then impact is something that your funders are

186.85.text: asking you to, to tell them about. "What impact

189.96.text: are you achieving?", "What evidence do you have

192.33.text: for the impact of this programme?" So it's kind of a

194.66.text: top down kind of demand that you have to meet.

199.90.text: Then on the other side you've got organisations

202.17.text: that are running programmes, whether they're helping

205.67.text: isolated older people to feel part of their

208.31.text: communities, whether they're helping young school

212.45.text: children from difficult backgrounds to get the

214.45.text: most out of school, they're doing these things

217.15.text: because they want to make a difference in these

218.92.text: people's lives. So that's a, a long winded way of

222.99.text: saying that, for, for those organisations they're

225.33.text: already doing this impact stuff, it's just that

227.69.text: they don't think of it in that way. And then they

230.23.text: have funders who are saying, "Well tell us about

234.87.text: those things often don't connect. So, ultimately

239.01.text: impact is incredibly important for the social

241.41.text: sector because it's what it does and getting to

244.78.text: grips to - with how you plan and manage, as well

248.62.text: as measure and learn from that impact it's just

251.85.text: what good organisations will be doing all the time.

255.15.text: They just may not think that.

257.26.text: So how should these organisations approach

259.66.text: social impact measurement? How do they need to,

261.86.text: to work differently do you think?

263.86.text: Well for me - and a lot of the work that we're doing is

267.60.text: about trying to, to simplify and clarify and get down to,

271.94.text: to first principles. So, if organisations essentially know

276.18.text: what they're trying to achieve, if they have clear goals,

279.95.text: and if they have some way of being able to

283.68.text: check in with reality to work out whether or not

286.55.text: they're achieving those goals and whether or not

288.45.text: they can improve the way that their programmes are

290.99.text: working towards those goals, that's all we're

293.79.text: essentially talking about. I think you can - you

296.60.text: can get into the - you know - the, the

301.23.text: control trials where what you're trying to achieve

303.80.text: is some sort of level of proof, or where - you

307.47.text: know - you're really trying to get a robust

309.81.text: evidence base for what you're doing, but for most

312.75.text: organisations who are working day-in, day-out, for me

316.48.text: this is more about incorporating a focus on impact

322.36.text: in ways that make sense to, to the people who are -

325.36.text: who are providing services, who are that the front lines,

327.66.text: who are managing on tight resources, rather than

331.06.text: that kind of highfalutin experimental approach.

334.97.text: So within the social sector and, and social

337.64.text: innovation we're often interested in long term

339.74.text: goals and long term measurement needs to be in place.

342.14.text: If you're thinking about tackling something

346.35.text: perhaps hard to show impact in a, in a short

349.08.text: period of time. How do we - how do we cope with

351.82.text: those challenges do you think, or address that?

354.89.text: I think that - you know - the answer to, to that

357.02.text: challenge lies in - you know - in, in exactly how

359.99.text: you stated it that if it's about achieving long

361.99.text: term impact then you've got to measure things over

364.23.text: the long term, and given that it's about achieving

368.17.text: long term impact, you've also got to I think,

371.40.text: take into account the complexity of the world that

374.41.text: you're dealing with and so not expect to be able

377.34.text: to isolate the specific impact of a particular

381.15.text: organisation or programme. Once you're - you know -

384.52.text: once you zoom out to the, the 10 year level to the,

387.92.text: the kind of the, the macro picture,

390.42.text: you're going to be able to look at change but it's going

393.89.text: to be very difficult to isolate in a kind of an

396.16.text: experimental way those different factors. I think

400.20.text: - I mean - I, I think that actually looking at

402.80.text: impact in that broader sense, so if there are a

405.44.text: whole bunch of different interventions and

407.04.text: organisations and government programmes working on

409.54.text: increasing educational attainment, you can be

413.01.text: following individual programmes and interventions at

416.02.text: a more micro level, but if you want to look at

418.15.text: that change at the, the whole macro level over the

421.32.text: long term, I think you have to do that, you have

424.22.text: to zoom out, but you have to set the, the kind of

427.53.text: the research design in place to be able to look

429.56.text: over that really long time period, and be more

433.73.text: comfortable with looking for - looking for change

437.70.text: as a whole rather than zeroing in on exactly how

441.14.text: this happened and exactly how that happened.

443.78.text: Do you think that can be a challenge in, in dealing

446.18.text: with government for the social sector though in terms

448.25.text: of governments and others want to see results

452.32.text: fairly soon and see the impact almost immediately

456.02.text: of, of change initiatives? Is that a, a challenge?

459.59.text: Yeah, I, I think it is. I think it's - I think

462.23.text: it's a challenge for - for human nature as well

464.23.text: because I think we all want to see results pretty

467.63.text: - pretty directly. But I think the thing is that

471.64.text: we're trying to deal with - you know - complex

474.44.text: interlinked problems and if we really want to

478.04.text: achieve change in the long term, and I guess if we

480.75.text: want to achieve systems change, then it's got to

484.45.text: be someone's job to get all of us together and

486.55.text: that includes government, that includes social

488.55.text: investors, that includes - you know - the social

494.09.text: say "Well hold on, let's - let's look at this from

496.10.text: a systems' perspective. Let's understand your

498.43.text: different constraints, and maybe, - you know - you

501.10.text: have three or five year planning horizons you have

503.70.text: to meet, but let's make sure that someone is

505.97.text: looking at this on a 10 year basis." And one of

509.38.text: the things that - you know - that NPC tries to do

511.71.text: is because we sit in between all of these

513.75.text: different institutions is to try and find out who

517.02.text: can look with the longest view and maybe sometimes

520.19.text: that's independent foundations who can invest over

523.39.text: a 10 year period. So - you know - you've got an,

526.53.text: an organisation like Inspiring Scotland back in

529.46.text: the UK that can invest on an eight year basis and,

533.20.text: and look for results over that period and it can

535.84.text: work with government, but it's going to be able to do

538.40.text: that on its own kind of agenda and then fit with and,

542.44.text: and align those different interests as we go along.

545.88.text: I mentioned earlier you're leading the Inspiring

548.18.text: Impact initiative. Can you tell us a little bit about that?

551.08.text: Sure. So, Inspiring Impact is a programme that we

556.12.text: kind of brought into being because we wanted to

559.09.text: look from a, a kind of a systems change

561.33.text: perspective at impact measurement across the

563.56.text: social sector. So I've been quite conscious that I

567.40.text: would be talking to a, a foundation or a, a

572.07.text: government department and I'd be saying "Work with

574.27.text: us to evaluate this programme. We'll do it in a way

577.14.text: that - you know - is very different from everyone else,"

579.71.text: and, and you've got all of these players in the

582.11.text: impact measurement field trying to carve out

584.62.text: their own uniqueness and trying to say that

586.92.text: "My approach is the right one and don't listen to

588.96.text: those other guys," and you know, it's kind of just

591.69.text: not true. Ninety percent of everything that

594.89.text: everyone's doing in this field I, I believe is

596.86.text: quite common. So we all believe in clarity of

599.30.text: goals and in having a theoretical model of how

601.87.text: your programme works and in collecting the right

605.00.text: kind of appropriate level of evidence, and so on.

609.68.text: So we figured actually could we have - have a more

612.08.text: collective programme here that would work across the

615.15.text: kind of the impact measurement field and try to -

619.85.text: try to get out there some, some clear

622.42.text: understanding, some best practice and some core

624.99.text: principles so that when, when someone asks you

627.93.text: what impact means, we're not all, all having a

630.83.text: discussion that says "Well I mean this but that

632.90.text: guy means that and he's wrong." That's never going

635.53.text: to bring along the social sector. So, we started a

639.94.text: couple of years ago from that approach of trying to

643.28.text: get everyone to work together and what we wanted to do is

647.28.text: see if we could achieve a real step change in the

649.72.text: level of impact measurement in, in the social sector.

653.22.text: Is it making a difference already, in your view?

656.29.text: I think it's too early to say that, but,

658.99.text: but given what we hoped to happen I think we're,

662.83.text: we're moving in, in the right direction. So in the first

665.97.text: year it was about developing that best practice guidance.

671.14.text: So we've developed a code of good impact practice

675.98.text: says some - you know - really, really

679.01.text: straightforward, accessible principles of, of how

682.55.text: an organisation should approach this. There's also

684.85.text: a set of funders' principles developed by grant

688.59.text: making organisations and there have been some,

692.39.text: some pieces of guidance and research around

695.90.text: developing common frameworks for measurement and

699.10.text: so on. But I think - you know - it, it's not that

701.80.text: everyone has taken those on board, changed what

703.80.text: they're doing, measured impact, come up with the results,

706.37.text: put those into their programmes and, and now

708.87.text: there are no social issues left in the UK.

710.88.text: But, this is - you know - this is a, we had a route map.

714.21.text: That's why this is a 10 year programme because we

716.52.text: think - you know - that's the minimum it's going to

718.18.text: take to - to really make that kind of difference.

720.35.text: Can you tell us a little bit more about the grant

722.22.text: funders' principles you just spoke about?

724.59.text: Sure. So working with the Association of

727.49.text: Charitable Foundations in the UK which is a

729.96.text: membership group for grant making bodies. Over a

734.17.text: period of a year they came together, a group of

737.40.text: funders and, and tried to work out "Well what are

740.04.text: the core principles from our perspective, both

742.94.text: about understanding the impact of those

744.98.text: organisations we fund, and also about understanding

747.85.text: our own impact as funding organisations?"

751.82.text: And the principles that they've come

753.02.text: up with are about the kind of the right mix

755.79.text: of proportionality for those organisations that

758.36.text: are funded and also for their approaches because

762.23.text: - you know - the, the grant making community is

764.40.text: very diverse. It, it wouldn't be right to, to set

769.20.text: a very high bar in terms of the levels of evidence

772.00.text: that people are expecting. More what we think is

775.98.text: needed is, is a more common understanding from

778.84.text: both sides from funded and funder of why we want

782.15.text: to know about impact. And you know, so a great

785.02.text: example would be if funders are, are asking for

788.32.text: evaluations what are they doing with them when

791.16.text: they get them? And this is something that we've -

793.39.text: you know - we've seen as a, a terrible problem in,

796.10.text: in the UK is that there are lots of evaluations

798.60.text: out there, but no one's doing anything with them

801.00.text: which is the most disempowering thing, the most

804.27.text: destructive thing for thinking about impact

806.27.text: measurement because no one's taking any blind bit

808.84.text: of notice. So, the principles there would

812.31.text: be understand the purpose of evaluation and have a

816.78.text: dialogue between funder and funded about what

819.92.text: comes out of an evaluation. Don't just ask for

822.49.text: something to be evaluated, then put it on the

823.86.text: shelf and then not fund that organisation ever

826.56.text: again even if they had good results. That's the

829.13.text: kind of approach that we've taken there.

833.20.text: Could you tell us a little bit about the

834.37.text: work you're doing with the European Commission and

837.14.text: moving this work to a Europe-wide basis?

841.34.text: Yeah, sure. Well, and I should say that I was

844.88.text: invited to be part of that European group, so -

847.65.text: you know - we've, we've certainly not initiated

849.65.text: that work, but so the, the European Commission as

854.35.text: part of a couple of programmes that it was

856.36.text: developing, one which is the European Social

858.99.text: Investment Funds and one which is a programme for

863.13.text: social change now I think called E A S I - EASI.

866.53.text: Both really needed to have a definition of impact

871.00.text: and impact measurement and a way of saying whether

874.14.text: or not it was taking place. So for the, for the

877.11.text: EUSIFs, for the social investment funds, they

879.41.text: needed to be able to say "If this is a European

882.58.text: Social Investment Fund, then it will invest in

886.39.text: these sorts of organisations," so social

889.42.text: organisations, and one of the things that is

892.29.text: important about those organisations is that they

894.56.text: are - they have an understanding of their social impact.

897.33.text: They're measuring it. So those definitions

899.70.text: needed to be in place. And so the European Union

902.97.text: brought together a, a group of experts from across

907.01.text: Europe to try and develop kind of what sort of

909.98.text: guidance would be needed to say "This is a EUSIF.

912.75.text: This can be part of one of these funds." And we're

917.92.text: now in the process of, of developing that guidance

920.72.text: so I can't say exactly what's going to come out,

922.76.text: but I think it's fair to say that there's been a

924.76.text: great deal of agreement across that, that working

928.23.text: group about really two things. So the first thing

934.13.text: that that group is completely agreed on is that

937.04.text: impact measurement needs to work for the frontline

939.14.text: organisations that are delivering social change.

942.31.text: So just as - you know - we've been discussing now,

944.41.text: it needs to be embedded in practice. It needs to

947.15.text: make sense to them so that they can manage and

949.58.text: improve programmes. So it shouldn't just be about

952.79.text: reporting to some - you know - higher agency,

957.12.text: whether that's an investor or government.

960.33.text: The second is that you cannot mandate a single

963.73.text: approach for measuring social impact, that - you

967.23.text: know - if one organisation is working on improving

970.54.text: young people's mental health and another is

972.67.text: working on, on increasing educational attainment

977.44.text: and another is working on better, more inclusive

981.71.text: employment for, for people with disabilities,

985.48.text: their impacts are so different, those people are

988.52.text: so different, their goals are so different you

990.52.text: cannot have a single way of measuring their impact.

993.89.text: But you can have common elements that you will expect

996.83.text: to see in those organisations and that's the

999.23.text: sort of approach that we've taken is to look

1001.67.text: at process and looking at standardisation of process,

1005.97.text: but not standardisation of what's actually being measured.

1010.48.text: And what have been the particular risks and

1012.64.text: challenges around working with the whole of Europe?

1017.38.text: Well obviously - you know - different nations have,

1022.99.text: different levels of sophistication around - or

1025.79.text: even of, of maturity of the social sector,

1028.03.text: different relationships between the state and the,

1031.46.text: the social sector, civil society, so there's - you

1034.80.text: know - there's a danger that you establish a

1036.37.text: framework that works from some expert's point of view,

1039.64.text: but doesn't work - you know - it, it doesn't

1042.27.text: work in Italy, but it works in the UK or it seems

1044.84.text: to be driven by a particular agenda. So clearly

1048.15.text: that's something that's quite a - quite a

1051.58.text: challenge. I think focusing on the core elements

1054.69.text: of process that you want to see in impact

1056.46.text: measurement means that that becomes pretty

1064.13.text: I think as long as we know that there aren't

1066.30.text: legislative frameworks that, that mean that a

1068.53.text: social sector organisation in one country couldn't

1071.84.text: take the same approach to, to measuring its impact

1075.34.text: as in another country then I think you're - you're okay.

1079.91.text: Because I think these are essentially things

1082.15.text: the things that we've been talking about transcend

1085.08.text: - you know - geography. Understanding what you're

1087.69.text: trying to achieve and whether you're achieving it,

1090.39.text: that doesn't feel like a particularly geographically

1092.62.text: constrained - you know - set of core, core principles.

1098.20.text: Tris, can you tell us a little bit - little

1099.83.text: bit about the work you're doing on common

1103.77.text: Sure. So, I said that you can't ever measure impact

1108.97.text: in the same way in completely different fields and I

1111.88.text: believe that's absolutely true, but you can

1114.91.text: measure impact in the same way within a field.

1117.62.text: So, what I mean is that if we're working towards - if

1121.25.text: there are multiple organisations working towards

1124.16.text: improving educational attainment of, of young people,

1128.83.text: then there should be common things

1130.83.text: actually that you can all measure. That's not to

1133.50.text: say that all organisations are actually going to

1136.80.text: deliver their work in the same way and we

1138.80.text: certainly don't want to encourage some sort of

1140.81.text: standardisation of the social sector. But we do

1143.68.text: believe at NPC that you can start to isolate the

1147.31.text: most important outcomes within a field that lead

1150.08.text: to the, the - the overall outcome that you're

1152.78.text: trying to achieve and then that yes, you should be

1155.35.text: able to measure those in common ways. So the work

1159.09.text: we're doing on, on common frameworks is within

1161.99.text: those specific fields trying to work with the

1164.46.text: whole field, work with the social sector

1167.20.text: organisations, also talk to and work with government,

1170.54.text: with funders to come up with some common

1172.87.text: framework where organisations can agree on 80 percent

1176.41.text: of what's most important and then move

1179.01.text: to measure them in the same way. So the, the most

1182.15.text: advanced initiative we're involved in on that is

1185.25.text: around youth employability and, and we're trying

1188.22.text: to take there the JET Framework which is the

1190.26.text: Journeys to Employment Framework and we're trying

1192.29.text: to work with the whole field actually to implement

1194.56.text: that so that organisations are all starting to

1198.23.text: measure the same things, and once you've done that

1201.20.text: some - some pretty amazing things start to happen

1203.80.text: because you can start to compare between different programmes.

1206.91.text: You can start to learn why this is working

1209.21.text: better than that, and funders actually can

1211.78.text: start to look across different organisations and

1214.71.text: interventions they're, they're funding and start

1216.38.text: to make more rational decisions about how to improve on

1219.69.text: the whole, the outcomes that they're achieving.

1223.16.text: Tris, can you tell us a bit about your visit to

1224.72.text: Australia and New Zealand and particularly what

1226.79.text: you're hoping to get out of the visit?

1228.56.text: This is my first time in Australia. I hope to do a

1231.83.text: lot of learning over the next couple of weeks about

1233.63.text: the sector, but certainly from my - I mean so I'm here to,

1240.77.text: to speak at a - the Centre for Social Impact

1243.14.text: conference in, in Melbourne next week, but also to,

1245.84.text: to visit with, with yourselves, with a number

1249.45.text: of different organisations, both in Australia and New Zealand.

1254.45.text: I suppose what I'm really here to understand is

1257.16.text: how similar the sector is here, the problems

1260.79.text: and challenges are here to, to back in

1264.23.text: the UK and to learn from that. And it just - it

1267.90.text: occurred to me actually just yesterday that when

1272.64.text: we talk about impact measurement we'll often talk

1274.94.text: about the counter-factual. We often talk about

1276.94.text: what would have happened in the absence of this

1279.34.text: thing that we're looking at, and with the kind of

1282.28.text: work that, that I do and that you do,

1284.65.text: it's remarkably difficult to think about what that

1286.72.text: counter-factual might be. You don't get to run

1289.02.text: experiments when you're - you know - when you're

1291.69.text: working at this kind of general level. So actually

1296.63.text: one way of understanding not the counter-factual

1299.80.text: but at least what might be happening in other

1302.80.text: contexts is how other countries look, and how

1308.41.text: impact measurement might be developing in

1310.54.text: Australia and New Zealand versus in the UK and how

1314.98.text: whether from seeing that we can then unpick some

1317.78.text: things about "Okay, so here it seems there's a,

1320.95.text: a push for let's say common measurement frameworks

1324.46.text: in a way that there isn't back in the UK. Can we

1327.76.text: understand that and learn from that?" So, one of

1330.10.text: the things I'm really keen on is, is learning from

1332.53.text: those differences as well as the similarities.

1336.27.text: Well thank you very much for your time today

1338.70.text: Tris. It's been great talking to you.

1340.31.text: No problem. Thanks for the invitation.
